Objet : TR: Christofle Insurance default.

 

Dear Ellen,

Thank you for your email. 

Further to our  tonight telecom,and to avoid any confusion these are the definition of business Income and Business interruption 

 

There is an important difference between business income and business interruption, although both are often related in the context of commercial insurance.

 

1. Business Income

• Definition: This refers to the income a business normally earns, typically including net profits and fixed operating expenses (such as salaries, rent, etc.).

• Example: A bakery that makes €10,000 in profit per month has a business income of €10,000/month.

 

 

2. Business Interruption

• Definition: This refers to the income a business normally earns, typically including net profits and fixed operating expenses (such as salaries, rent, etc.).

• Example: A bakery that makes €10,000 in profit per month has a business income of €10,000/month.

 

 

2. Business Interruption

• Definition: This refers to a loss of business income due to an unexpected event (such as a fire, flood, or another insured peril) that forces the business to temporarily or partially suspend its operations.

• Business Interruption Insurance: This type of insurance is designed to compensate for lost income during the period when the business cannot operate normally.

• Example: If the bakery is destroyed by a fire and has to close for 2 months, a business interruption policy could cover the €20,000 of lost income, and possibly additional costs (like temporary rental or replacement equipment).

 

Please tell  me what kind of formula you want. You can ask Mr. Bollet’s advice. You can call  also Enrique giving him the 2 definitions 

I look forward to hearing back from you the soonest Please 

Nice day 

 

Joe Nasr

Head of General Insurance

 



We do everything we can to make your life easier and find solutions  

 

Nasco France

171 rue de Buzenval, 92380 Garches

Sorry for our delay in response, it’s a bit complicated as we are seeking for our parent company’s approval and there are many stakeholders involved in this issue,

However, I do want to discuss with you about this request,

 

Business income is a key coverage for us, as it goes directly to the tenant’s ability to maintain payments in the event of a casualty.  

Christofle is required to carry a minimum Business Income of $500K.

-Y2023  $ 1,757K

-Y2024  $ 2,255K

-Y2025  $ 1,134 as of end of May, $2,672K as forecasted for Y2025,  so we already over achieved that $ 500K 2 weeks ago,

-Y2024  $ 2,255K

-Y2025  $ 1,134 as of end of May, $2,672K as forecasted for Y2025,  so we already over achieved that $ 500K 2 weeks ago,
